questions.question: Except in which of the following is laryngeal crepitus not present?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Prevertebral Abscess Explanation: Laryngeal crepitus refers to the movement of the larynx over the cervical spine during swallowing. It is absent when the larynx is fixed due to an underlying pathology. In a prevertebral abscess , infection spreads in the prevertebral space , restricting the mobility of the larynx, thus abolishing crepitus. Laryngeal Crepitus and Its Absence Condition Laryngeal Crepitus Presence Reason Post-cricoid malignancy Present (unless advanced) Tumors in this area usually do not fix the larynx early Hypopharyngeal abscess Present or reduced May affect laryngeal movement but not always abolish crepitus Parapharyngeal abscess Present or reduced Can restrict lateral movement but does not fix larynx completely Prevertebral abscess Absent Fixes the larynx to the spine, preventing movement Incorrect Options: Post-cricoid malignancy (Option A): is incorrect because early-stage malignancies do not fix the larynx. Crepitus is lost only in advanced cases where the tumor invades deeper tissues. Hypopharyngeal abscess (Option B): is incorrect because while it can partially restrict laryngeal movement, crepitus is not always completely absent unless the abscess is large. Parapharyngeal abscess (Option C): is incorrect because this abscess is lateral to the larynx and does not always cause fixation. However, extensive cases may restrict movement. Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 8th edition, pages 313-315

questions.question: What nerve is most likely to be damaged when the cough reflex is impaired due to alcohol ingestion and other conditions, resulting in the prevention of foreign body entry into the laryngeal inlet?
questions.explanation: branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, which is, in turn, a branch of the vagus nerve. It supplies the laryngeal mucosa above the vocal cords and prevents aspiration of any foreign substances by protective cough reflex. Alcohol ingestion can cause alcohol-induced inhibition of the Central Nervous System, which can affect the internal laryngeal nerve, resulting in reduced laryngeal sensations and masked laryngeal reflexes. The larynx receives both motor and sensory nerve supply from branches of the vagus nerve. Motor innervation : Recurrent laryngeal nerve - All muscles that move the vocal cords, including abductors, adductors, and tensors. Except the cricothyroid muscle. External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve - cricothyroid muscle. (Option C ruled out) Sensory innervation : The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve - above the vocal cords. (Option A) Recurrent laryngeal nerve - below the vocal cords. Recurrent laryngeal nerve anatomy : (Option D ruled out) The right recurrent laryngeal nerve branches from the vagus at the level of the subclavian artery, looping around it before ascending between the trachea and esophagus. The left recurrent laryngeal nerve arises at the arch of the aorta, loops around it, and ascends along the tracheoesophageal groove, giving it a longer course compared to the right nerve, making it more prone to injury. Superior laryngeal nerve : Origin - from the inferior ganglion of the vagus nerve; courses behind the internal carotid artery; divides into external and internal branches at the level of the greater cornua of the hyoid bone. The external branch innervates the cricothyroid muscle. The internal branch provides sensory innervation to the larynx and hypopharynx after piercing through the thyrohyoid membrane. Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX): This nerve provides sensory innervation to the posterior third of the tongue, pharynx, and tonsils. While it contributes to the gag reflex and has some role in swallowing, it's not the primary nerve responsible for sensation in the supraglottic larynx that triggers the cough reflex.

questions.question: CT scan of a patient with laryngeal carcinoma is shown below. What is the staging? A. Τ 1 ΝΟΜΟ
questions.explanation: carcinoma is T4N1M0 since there is an invasion of the tumor into the cricoid and thyroid cartilage, and there is an extension of the tumor into adjacent soft tissues of the neck, which includes the strap muscles, thyroid, and deep extrinsic muscles of the tongue. There is single, ipsilateral lymph node involvement measuring less than 3cm in size with no distant metastasis. Subglottis T1 Tumor is limited to the subglottis. (Option A ruled out) T2 Tumor extends to the vocal cord(s) with normal or impaired mobility. (Option C ruled out) T3 Tumor limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation. (Option D ruled out) T4a Tumor invades cricoid or thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of tongue, strap muscles, thyroid or esophagus). (Option B) T4b Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases the carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures. Regional lymph nodes (N) Nx Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed. N0 No regional lymph node metastasis. N1 Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, 3 cm or less in greatest dimension. N2 Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension. N2a Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension. N2b Metastasis in multiple ipsilateral

questions.question: How should a patient with diphtheria and right vocal fold palsy be treated?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Thyroplasty type 1 Explanation: In a patient with diphtheria and right vocal fold palsy, thyroplasty type 1 is the most appropriate treatment. Thyroplasty type 1 is a surgical procedure used to improve vocal fold closure in cases of vocal fold paralysis. This procedure involves the insertion of an implant to push the paralyzed vocal fold towards the midline, improving voice quality and airway protection. It is especially helpful in cases of vocal fold paralysis caused by infections like diphtheria, which can result in nerve damage affecting vocal fold movement. Incorrect Options: Wait and watch (Option A) : Waiting and watching may be appropriate in some cases of vocal fold paralysis that resolve spontaneously over time. However, given that the patient has vocal fold palsy with potential functional impairment (speech and airway protection), active intervention such as thyroplasty is typically preferred to improve outcomes. Gelfoam injection (Option B) : Gelfoam injection is sometimes used in laryngeal procedures for temporary volume augmentation, but it is not the definitive treatment for vocal fold paralysis. It may not provide long-term results compared to thyroplasty. Fat injection (Option D) : Fat injection, similar to Gelfoam, is another method for increasing vocal fold bulk and improving closure, but it is less commonly used for permanent correction compared to thyroplasty. Fat injections can lead to resorption over time, reducing their long-term efficacy. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Page 350, 351

questions.question: Which of the subsequent laryngeal cartilages is least prone to calcification?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Epiglottis Explanation: Epiglottis is least prone to calcification because it is composed of elastic cartilage , which resists calcification compared to hyaline cartilage. Elastic cartilage maintains its flexibility and does not undergo the age-related ossification seen in other laryngeal cartilages. Type of Cartilage Paired Cartilage Unpaired Cartilage Hyaline Cartilage (Calcifies with age) Arytenoid Thyroid, Cricoid Elastic Cartilage Corniculate, Cuneiform Epiglottis Epiglottis Unpaired Elastic Cartilage Shape: Leaf-shaped yellow elastic cartilage. Location: Forms the anterior wall of the laryngeal inlet. Attachments: Connected to the hyoid bone by the hyoepiglottic ligament , dividing it into suprahyoid and infrahyoid portions. The petiole attaches it to the thyroid cartilage just above the vocal cords. Anterior Surface: Preepiglottic Space: Located in front of the epiglottis, between the anterior surface and the thyrohyoid membrane/upper thyroid cartilage. Filled with fat, it may be involved in supraglottic cancers or the base of tongue carcinomas. Posterior Surface: Tubercle of Epiglottis: A bulge that may obstruct the view of the anterior commissure during indirect laryngoscopy. Contains pits for mucous glands and occasional perforations, which may facilitate cancer spread to the preepiglottic space. Clinical Significance: Cancer Spread: Supraglottic cancers can invade the pre-epiglottic space through epiglottic perforations. Non-Essential for Swallowing: The epiglottis can be safely amputated in cases of cancer or trauma without significant risk of aspiration. Thyroid (Option A) : The thyroid cartilage is made of hyaline cartilage , which tends to calcify with age, especially after the third decade of life. Cricoid (Option B) : Like the thyroid cartilage, the cricoid cartilage is also composed of hyaline cartilage and is prone to calcification as part of the normal ageing process. Arytenoid (Option C) : The arytenoid cartilage consists of hyaline cartilage in its base and elastic cartilage in its apex, but the hyaline portion is susceptible to calcification over time.

questions.question: Which of the following is not employed in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation?
questions.explanation: anatomical structures it targets (vocal folds) are no longer present. Vocal rehabilitation-methods: After laryngectomy, the patient loses his speech completely. The various methods by which communication can be established are given below: Oesophageal Speech (Option B ruled out) In this, the patient is taught to swallow air and hold it in the upper esophagus and then slowly eject it from the esophagus into the pharynx. The patient can speak 6-10 words before re-swallowing air. The voice is rough but loud and understandable. Artificial Larynx It is used in those who fail to learn oesophageal speech. 1. Electrolarynx: Its vibrating disc is held against the soft tissues of the neck and a low-pitched sound is produced in the hypopharynx which is further modulated into speech by the tongue, lips, teeth, and palate. 2. Transoral pneumatic device It is a transoral device. Here vibrations produced in a rubber diaphragm are carried by a plastic tube into the back of the oral cavity where sound is converted into speech by modulators. This is a pneumatic type of device and uses expired air from the tracheostome to vibrate the diaphragm. Tracheo-Oesophageal Speech (Option A ruled out) Here an attempt is made to carry air from the trachea to the esophagus or hypopharynx by the creation of a skin-lined fistula or by placement of an artificial prosthesis. The vibrating column of air entering the pharynx is then modulated into speech. This technique has the disadvantage of food entering the trachea. These days prostheses (Blom-Singer or Panje) are being used to shunt air from the trachea to the esophagus They have inbuilt valves which work only in one direction thus preventing problems of aspiration. Olfactory Rehabilitation: (Option D ruled out) After laryngectomy, smell is lost because air no longer passes through the nose. This also means patients can't detect dangerous environmental odours like smoke or gas. To address this, a technique called "polite yawning" can be taught. This involves: Lowering the jaw, floor of mouth, and tongue while keeping lips closed. This creates negative pressure in the mouth and throat, drawing air through the nose. Repeating this maneuver several times can help restore some sense of smell and allow detection of environmental hazards.

questions.question: What is a drug called Mitomycin-C used for in medical treatment?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Subglottic stenosis Mitomycin-C is an antineoplastic antibiotic that acts as a DNA cross-linking agent and is used topically in various medical and surgical conditions to inhibit fibroblast proliferation and scar formation . In ENT practice, it is commonly used in the treatment of subglottic stenosis to prevent restenosis following airway dilation or surgical intervention. It is applied topically to the affected area after dilation or surgical removal of fibrotic tissue to reduce the risk of recurrence by inhibiting fibroblast proliferation and excessive scarring. Rhinocerebral mucormycosis (Option B): Incorrect because the treatment of rhinocerebral mucormycosis primarily involves amphotericin B and surgical debridement , not Mitomycin-C. Adenoidectomy (Option C): Incorrect because Mitomycin-C is not used in routine adenoidectomy . The procedure involves surgical removal of hypertrophied adenoid tissue without the need for an antifibrotic agent. Tympanoplasty (Option D): Incorrect because Mitomycin-C is not used in tympanoplasty . This procedure aims to repair the tympanic membrane and ossicular chain, and there is no role for an antifibrotic agent. Reference: Scott-Brown's Otorhinolaryngology and Head and Neck Surgery 8th Edition - 2018 • Page no: 1088, 1083

questions.question: Which of the following is a life-threatening nerve injury?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Bilateral Complete RLN Palsy Explanation: This condition leads to both vocal cords being fixed in a median or paramedian position, causing severe airway obstruction. Patients experience stridor and dyspnea, making this the most life-threatening form of recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury. Emergency management often requires tracheostomy or vocal cord lateralization surgery. Reference: Dhingra's Diseases Of Ear, Nose And Throat, & Head and Neck Surgery, 8th edition, Pages 348, 349.

questions.question: In a patient with laryngeal cancer who has undergone a total laryngectomy, determine the mode of voice production depicted in the provided image.
questions.explanation: an electro larynx for voice production. It is a handheld device that vibrates to generate sound, which the patient then shapes into speech by moving their mouth. The electro larynx is an effective alternative for patients who cannot use a tracheoesophageal prosthesis and provides a mechanical, yet functional, voice. Electro Larynx: The electro larynx is commonly used in patients who have undergone a total laryngectomy , a procedure that removes the larynx and disrupts normal voice production. The device works by emitting vibrations, which the patient can articulate to form words. Although it can be mechanical-sounding, it remains a popular and accessible method for speech restoration. Incorrect Options: Tracheoesophageal prosthesis (Option A): is incorrect because it involves the use of a small valve between the trachea and esophagus to produce speech, not a mechanical device. Chicago implant (Option B): is incorrect because the Chicago implant is a type of prosthesis used for tracheoesophageal speech but does not directly generate sound like the electro larynx. Esophageal speech (Option D): is incorrect because this method involves swallowing air and releasing it from the esophagus to produce speech, which is different from using a mechanical device like the electro larynx. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose & Throat - PL Dhingra - 8th Edition • Page no: 365

questions.question: A 2-year-old child presented with the following X-ray finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Acute laryngotracheobronchitis: Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup): The "steeple sign" seen on the X-ray is characteristic of acute laryngotracheobronchitis, commonly known as croup. This sign refers to the narrowing of the subglottic airway, which appears as a "steeple" or "church steeple" shape on the frontal view of the X-ray. Croup typically presents with symptoms such as a barking cough, stridor, and respiratory distress in children. Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup): Acute laryngotracheobronchitis, or croup, is a viral infection most commonly caused by parainfluenza viruses, although other viruses like RSV can also cause it. It leads to inflammation and swelling of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi, which results in airway narrowing and the characteristic "barking" cough. The "steeple sign" seen on X-ray is a diagnostic clue, reflecting subglottic narrowing, which is a hallmark of the disease. Diagnosis and Treatment of Acute Epiglottitis vs. Croup Aspect Acute Epiglottitis Croup (Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis) Diagnosis Visualisation: Red and swollen epiglottis (avoid indirect laryngoscopy to prevent airway obstruction). Lateral Neck X-ray: "Thumb sign" indicating swollen epiglottis. Differentiated based on clinical features (e.g., absence of drooling, voice quality). The "steeple sign" on an X-ray AP view shows a narrowing of the upper airway, often seen in croup. X-Ray

questions.question: What is the most likely reason for a patient experiencing breathing difficulties and unsuccessful extubation after undergoing a total thyroidectomy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury A patient experiencing breathing difficulties and unsuccessful extubation after a total thyroidectomy strongly suggests bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury . The recurrent laryngeal nerves supply motor innervation to all intrinsic laryngeal muscles (except the cricothyroid). Bilateral injury causes bilateral vocal cord paralysis in a paramedian position , leading to airway obstruction , stridor , and inability to extubate due to compromised glottic airway. Superior laryngeal nerve injury (Option A): Incorrect because this nerve supplies the cricothyroid muscle , affecting voice modulation and pitch , but does not cause airway obstruction . Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury (Option B): Incorrect because unilateral RLN injury leads to hoarseness , not significant respiratory distress or extubation failure . The contralateral vocal cord compensates , allowing adequate breathing. Hematoma (Option D): Incorrect because while a postoperative neck hematoma can cause airway compression , it typically presents with swelling, bruising, and respiratory distress within a few hours postoperatively. Immediate surgical evacuation would relieve symptoms, unlike bilateral RLN injury , which persists despite hematoma evacuation. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose & Throat - PL Dhingra - 8th Edition, Page no: 348, 349

questions.question: Which of the following organisms does not cause croup?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Rhinovirus Explanation: Croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) is a viral infection that causes subglottic airway inflammation , leading to barking cough, stridor, and hoarseness . It is most commonly caused by Parainfluenza viruses (types 1 and 2) , followed by RSV and influenza . Rhinovirus , however, is primarily associated with the common cold and does not typically cause croup. Croup (Laryngotracheobronchitis) Feature Description Cause Parainfluenza virus (Types 1, 2, 3) - most common , RSV, Influenza, Adenovirus Age Group 6 months - 3 years (most common) Symptoms 1. Barking cough 2. Inspiratory stridor 3. Hoarseness 4. Respiratory distress Steeple Sign on X-ray Subglottic narrowing on AP neck X-ray Treatment Mild: Supportive care, humidified air Moderate-Severe: Dexamethasone + Nebulized Epinephrine Incorrect Options: Parainfluenza 1 (Option A): is incorrect because Parainfluenza virus type 1 is the most common cause of croup . Parainfluenza 2 (Option B): is incorrect because Parainfluenza type 2 also causes croup, though less frequently than type 1 . RSV (Option D): is incorrect because Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) can cause croup, though it is more commonly associated with bronchiolitis . Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Edition 21 page no: 2202-2205 OP Ghai Essential Pediatrics Edition 10 page no:391, 392 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441873/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK431070/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7173542/

questions.question: A 65 year old male presented with history of dysphagia, halitosis and aspiration pneumonia. A barium swallow was done and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Zenker’s Diverticulum Explanation: The patient presents with dysphagia, halitosis, and aspiration pneumonia , which are classical symptoms of Zenker’s diverticulum . Barium swallow typically shows a posterior pharyngeal pouch originating from Killian’s dehiscence . Zenker’s Diverticulum Feature Description Definition A false diverticulum formed due to herniation of pharyngeal mucosa through Killian’s dehiscence Cause Cricopharyngeal muscle dysfunction leading to increased pressure and pouch formation Symptoms 1. Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) 2. Regurgitation of undigested food 3. Halitosis (bad breath) 4. Aspiration pneumonia Diagnosis Barium swallow X-ray (shows a posterior pharyngeal pouch) Treatment Endoscopic diverticulotomy (Dohlman’s procedure) or open diverticulectomy in large cases Incorrect Options: Diffuse esophageal spasm (Option A): is incorrect because diffuse esophageal spasm presents with intermittent chest pain and dysphagia , and barium swallow shows a "corkscrew esophagus" , not a diverticulum. Achalasia cardia (Option B): is incorrect because achalasia presents with progressive dysphagia to solids and liquids, with regurgitation . Barium swallow shows a "bird’s beak" appearance , not a pharyngeal pouch. Esophageal cancer (Option D): is incorrect because esophageal cancer presents with progressive dysphagia, weight

questions.question: What is the TNM staging for a patient with carcinoma in the pyriform fossa, presenting with a 5 cm lesion on laryngoscopy, non-mobile right vocal folds, no lymph node involvement, and no distant metastasis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) T3N0M0 Explanation: The TNM staging for pyriform fossa carcinoma follows the AJCC (American Joint Committee on Cancer) classification. T3 : Tumor >4 cm or with vocal cord fixation N0 : No regional lymph node involvement M0 : No distant metastasis Since the patient has a 5 cm lesion (T3 criterion) and non-mobile vocal cords (vocal cord fixation), the correct stage is T3N0M0 . TNM Staging of Hypopharyngeal Cancer (Including Pyriform Fossa) Stage Tumor Size/Extent Vocal Cord Mobility Lymph Node Involvement Metastasis T1 Tumor confined to one subsite of hypopharynx Normal No nodes (N0) No (M0) T2 Tumor extends to more than one subsite or adjacent areas Normal N0 M0 T3 Tumor >4 cm or vocal cord fixation Fixed N0 M0 T4a Tumor invades adjacent structures (e.g., thyroid/cricoid cartilage, hyoid, thyroid gland, esophagus) Fixed N0/N+ M0 T4b Tumor invades prevertebral fascia, encases carotid artery, or involves mediastinal structures Fixed N0/N+ M0 Incorrect Options: T2N0M0 (Option A): is incorrect because T2 is for tumors extending to multiple subsites but <4 cm and without vocal cord fixation . T4aN0M0 (Option C): is incorrect because T4a requires invasion into adjacent structures (e.g., cartilage, esophagus), which is not mentioned in this case . T4bN0M0 (Option D): is incorrect because T4b involves invasion of prevertebral fascia, carotid artery, or mediastinum, none of which are present in this case . Reference: Scott-Brown’s Otorhinolaryngology: Head and Neck Surgery; 7th EditionPg 2645,2646

questions.question: A child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On examination, you notice the inspiratory stridor in the child, and the laryngeal examination is as below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Laryngomalacia Explanation: Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of congenital stridor , presenting in infants with inspiratory stridor that worsens when supine or feeding . Laryngeal examination typically shows an omega-shaped epiglottis and redundant arytenoid mucosa , which collapse during inspiration. Laryngomalacia Feature Description Cause Congenital floppy laryngeal cartilage , especially affecting the epiglottis and arytenoids Symptoms Inspiratory stridor (worse when supine, feeding, or crying) Onset At birth or within the first few weeks of life , peaks at 4–8 months , resolves by 12–24 months Diagnosis Flexible laryngoscopy → shows omega-shaped epiglottis , redundant arytenoid mucosa Treatment Observation in mild cases, surgical intervention (supraglottoplasty) in severe cases Incorrect Options: Vocal cord paralysis (Option A): is incorrect because it causes biphasic stridor (both inspiratory and expiratory) and weak cry , unlike the isolated inspiratory stridor seen in laryngomalacia. Subglottic stenosis (Option B): is incorrect because it causes biphasic stridor and is often associated with prolonged intubation history . Laryngeal papilloma (Option C): is incorrect because it causes progressive hoarseness and voice changes , whereas laryngomalacia primarily causes stridor without voice involvement.

questions.question: A patient presents with hoarseness of voice. On examination an ulceroproliferative mass is seen on the right vocal cord; the cord was however mobile. There is no lymph node involvement and no metastasis. Which of the following is the best treatment modality for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Radiotherapy Explanation: In this case, the patient presents with an ulceroproliferative mass on the right vocal cord with mobile vocal cords , no lymph node involvement , and no metastasis . This suggests an early-stage laryngeal carcinoma (likely T1 or T2 ), where the tumor is confined to the vocal cord without spread to adjacent tissues or lymph nodes. For early-stage tumors of the larynx, radiotherapy is the treatment of choice. It is effective in treating such localized tumors, helps preserve voice function, and avoids the need for more invasive procedures like surgery. Laryngeal Cancer Treatment: Laryngeal cancer typically presents with hoarseness , which may be the initial symptom. When a tumor is localized to the vocal cords (as in this case), and there is no evidence of regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis , radiotherapy offers an effective non-surgical option. It preserves the vocal cords and the patient's voice function, making it the preferred treatment modality for early-stage cancers. In advanced laryngeal cancers (involving surrounding structures or metastasis), more radical treatments like total laryngectomy or chemotherapy may be necessary, but this is not the case here. Incorrect Options: Total laryngectomy (Option A): is incorrect because the tumor appears to be in an early, localized stage, and radiotherapy should be preferred for such cases to preserve the larynx and voice. Conservative laryngectomy (Option C): is incorrect because while partial laryngectomy may be considered for certain cases, radiotherapy is typically the first-line treatment for early-stage vocal cord cancer with no spread. Chemotherapy (Option D): is incorrect because chemotherapy is generally reserved for advanced or metastatic cancers , which is not the case in this patient, as there is no evidence of metastasis or lymph node involvement. Reference: P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery - 7th Edition • Page no: 351

questions.question: A young male who is a professional trumpet blower presented with a swelling on the left side of the neck. On examination, there is a gurgling sound when compressing the swelling. As the X-ray neck was inconclusive a CT neck was taken which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Laryngocele Explanation: The most likely diagnosis is Laryngocele . A laryngocele is an air-filled dilation of the saccule of the larynx, which can communicate with the laryngeal lumen. The gurgling sound when compressing the swelling suggests the presence of air or fluid within the sac. This condition is often associated with activities that increase intra-abdominal or intrathoracic pressure, such as blowing a trumpet or playing other wind instruments. The CT scan would reveal a characteristic air-filled structure adjacent to the larynx, confirming the diagnosis. Laryngocele: A laryngocele is a condition where a portion of the laryngeal mucosa becomes dilated, typically due to increased pressure, causing an air-filled sac to form. It can be classified into internal (confined within the larynx) or external (extending outside the larynx into the neck). Laryngoceles are commonly seen in individuals who perform activities that involve frequent increases in intrathoracic or abdominal pressure, such as trumpet players or other wind instrument musicians. The clinical presentation may include a neck

questions.question: A 60 year old patient presented with Hoarseness of voice. On examination following finding shown below. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: secondary tumors (metastases) in the neck region , most commonly originating from primary tumors elsewhere in the body. Depending on the location and extent of metastasis, it can potentially cause hoarseness of voice, especially if the tumor involves the vocal cords. Incorrect options: Option A. Multinodular goiter : A multinodular goiter refers to an enlarged thyroid gland with multiple nodules. While a large goiter can cause compression and hoarseness of voice, it is not the most likely diagnosis based solely on hoarseness. Option C. TB lymphadenitis: TB lymphadenitis refers to the inflammation and swelling of lymph nodes due to tuberculosis infection. While it can cause neck swelling and compression of adjacent structures, it is less likely to cause hoarseness of voice as a primary symptom. OptionD. Sternomastoid tumor : Sternomastoid tumors are rare and usually benign growths within the sternocleidomastoid muscle of the neck. They are typically asymptomatic and would not be a likely cause of hoarseness of voice. Reference: .

questions.question: What is the truth about the condition of a 40-year-old male teacher who presents with a complaint of hoarseness of voice for 5 months, worsening gradually, and is a non-smoker and social drinker? Laryngoscopic examination reveals nodules in the vocal cords.

options.A: Laser therapy is the treatment of choice
options.B: It occurs at the junction of anterior 1/3 and posterior 2/3
options.C: Requires excision as its potentially malignant

questions.explanation: nodule based on the history and occupation of the patient. It occurs at the junction of the anterior one-third with the posterior two-thirds, as this is the area of maximum vibration of the cord and thus subject to maximum trauma. Singer's nodule Singer's nodule is a nodule that develops on vocal cords due to excessive or improper use of vocal cords It is common among singers and teachers due to excessive use of cords during their lifetime. The junction of anterior 1/3 and posterior 2/3 is the area of maximum vibration of vocal cords. Incorrect Options Option A: Laser therapy is the treatment of choice Mild cases of vocal nodules can be treated conservatively by educating the patient on the proper use of voice. Laser therapy is not the treatment of choice. Option C: Requires excision as its potentially malignant Vocal nodules are hard, rough, noncancerous growths. They are benign and have no potential for malignancy. Option D: Most common symptom is pain Most common symptom is hoarseness or rough voice There may be a feeling of lumpiness in the neck. Vocal fatigue from prolonged phonation is another common symptom. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following signs can be appreciated in the given X-ray?
questions.explanation: characteristic of a button battery aspiration. The double ring appearance is due to the unique structure of a button battery, where the edge of the battery gives a double contour. Incorrect Options: Option A - Steeple Sign: The steeple sign is associated with croup (laryngotracheobronchitis). Option B - String Sign: The string sign is observed in pyloric stenosis. Option C - Thumb Sign: The thumb sign is associated with epiglottitis.

questions.question: A patient was presented to the OPD with a sudden onset of shortness of breath. Identify the condition with the radiological image given below.
questions.explanation: respiratory distress in children or adults. The radiological image shows the "Steeple Sign" or a narrowing of the subglottic airway , which is characteristic of Laryngotracheobronchitis (commonly referred to as Croup ). Other Options: Epiglottitis (Option A) : Characterized by supraglottic narrowing , often with a thumbprint sign on imaging, and presents with severe respiratory distress and drooling . Laryngomalacia (Option D) : A congenital condition causing floppy epiglottis , leading to stridor but typically diagnosed clinically, not with acute symptoms and not showing "steeple sign." Bronchitis (Option C) : Does not typically cause subglottic narrowing ; it involves inflammation of the bronchi and is usually seen in older children/adults with productive cough . Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Pg 456

questions.question: Based on the provided chest X-ray, which of the following procedures would be most challenging to perform?
questions.explanation: right side, which will make it very difficult to perform a tracheostomy. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are not difficult to perform in a patient with a deviated trachea. Reference: .

questions.question: A patient with prolonged intubation complained of respiratory distress. Which of the following staging systems is used to stage the condition shown in the image?
questions.explanation: designed to stage laryngotracheal stenosis, particularly the narrowing of the airway after intubation or tracheostomy. It grades the stenosis based on the percentage of the lumen that is narrowed. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are not used to classify subglottic stenosis. Reference: .

questions.question: A singer is finding difficulty in raising the pitch of her voice. On examination, her vocal cords were depressed and bowing. Which of the following muscles is involved?
questions.explanation: It is a tensor muscle of the vocal cords. When there is dysfunction or paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle, the vocal cords are not properly tensed, leading to difficulty in raising the pitch. Incorrect Options: Option B and D - Interarytenoid and Lateral arytenoid are adductors of the vocal cord. Option C - The posterior cricoarytenoid is an abductor of the vocal cords. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following stains can be used to identify a laryngeal mass during laryngeal examination?
questions.explanation: laryngoscopy is a reliable adjunct to the early and precise diagnosis of carcinoma of the larynx. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are not used to identify a laryngeal mass during laryngeal examination.

questions.question: Which of the statement is true regarding laryngomalacia?

options.C: Most common congenital abnormality in newborn
options.D: Surgical management is required in most children

questions.explanation: is characterised by excessive flaccidity of epiglottis or supraglottis (Malacia: Weakness/ flaccidity of tissue). Laryngomalacia or congenital laryngeal stridor Most common congenital abnormality of the larynx. During inspiration, an excessively flaccid supraglottic larynx gets sucked in and causes the symptoms. Clinical features: Presents at birth or immediately after Stridor: Increases on crying (increased negative intrathoracic pressure pulls the epiglottis inward, covering the laryngeal inlet) Stridor present in supine position (as the epiglottis covers the laryngeal inlet) Subsides in prone position (as the epiglottis falls away from the larynx) Cyanosis seen sometimes Normal cry Usually disappears by 2 years of age Investigations: Direct laryngoscopy: Elongated epiglottis, curled upon itself giving an “omega-shaped” appearance . Floppy aryepiglottic folds Prominent aretynoids Flexible laryngoscopy is the most preferred Management: Conservative treatment in most cases Tracheostomy: If severe respiratory obstruction Supraglottoplasty: If severe laryngomalacia Incorrect Options: Expiratory stridor (Option A) : This is a wrong statement as laryngomalacia is associated with Inspiratory stridor Improve in supine position (Option B): This condition worsens in supine position. Surgical management is required in most children (Option D): Laryngomalacia usually resolves by 1-2 years of age and can be managed conservatively.Surgical management plays a role if conservative management fails to resolve. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 331

questions.question: A 45-year-old teacher presents to the physician with complaints of hoarseness and voice fatigue. She reports that these symptoms have been gradually worsening over the past few months, especially towards the end of the school day. She denies any history of smoking or excessive alcohol consumption. Flexible laryngoscopy image is given below. what is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: region of junction of anterior and middle 1/3rd of vocal cords It is mostly seen in teachers, singers, etc Vocal Nodule (Singer or screamer's nodule) Cause Chronic vocal abuse (teachers, actors, vendors or pop singers. ) Laterality Bilateral or symmetrical Location Free edge of vocal cord at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd. This is the area of maximum vibration of the vocal cord. Appearance Sessile , Reddish in the early stage and white in the chronic stage Symptoms Hoarseness, vocal fatigue and neck pain on prolonged phonation. Treatment Initially, voice rest. If it fails - microscopic excision without injuring the vocal ligament Speech therapy Incorrect Options: Reinkes edema (Option B): This is an accumulation of the oedematous tissue or the myxomatous tissue in Reinke's space. It involves the anterior I rd which is the membranous portion of the vocal cord. It has a Bag with a water-like appearance due to bilateral symmetrical swellings of the vocal cord Vocal polyp (Option C): This is a unilateral pedunculated lesion present at the junction of anterior and middle I rd of vocal chords. Keratosis larynx (Option D): Causes due to chronic irritation by smoking, tobacco chewing, excessive voice abuse, and reflux. Can be treated by Stripping of the vocal cord. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 331

questions.question: A 2-year-old child presents to the emergency department with a barking cough and noisy breathing. An anteroposterior view of x ray of the neck shows a steeple sign. What type of stridor is most commonly associated with this presentation?
questions.explanation: inflammation of larynx, trachea, and bronchi The stridor that happens between vocal cords and the cervical trachea is biphasic Diagnosis: Anteroposterior view of the neck: steeple sign due to subglottic stenosis. Symptoms: Malaise and fever: Low grade or no fever, and the child is not toxic Respiratory: Biphasic stridor. Digestive: Not present or mild. Phonatory/ voice: Change in voice and cough, barking seal-like cough. Incorrect Options: Inspiratory (Option A): This kind of stridor is seen in inflammatory conditions that happen above the vocal cords Expiratory (Option B): This stridor is seen when inflammation happens in the trachea, bronchi Uniphasic (Option D): There is no such term, and it can be eliminated by explaining the above options. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 267

questions.question: Which vitamin deficiency leads to Laryngismus stridulus?
questions.explanation: stridulus Laryngismus stridulus: Aspect Details Etiology Hypocalcemia (rickets, hypoparathyroidism) GERD Viral infections Allergies Stress/emotions Cold air, smoke Rare: neurological issues Symptoms Sudden stridor Breath-holding Cough/choke Cyanosis Anxiety Normal between attacks No fever (unless infection) Investigations Serum calcium, phosphate, vitamin D Chest X-ray Laryngoscopy (if needed) pH probe (for GERD) Allergy tests Treatment Acute: Calm child Humidified air Oxygen if needed Upright position Underlying cause: Correct calcium/vitamin D Treat GERD Avoid allergens Supportive care for infections Psychological support Prevention Adequate nutrition (vitamin D, calcium) Manage triggers Parental education Incorrect Options: Options A, B & D: Vitamin K, E and A deficiencies do not lead to Laryngismus stridulus. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 279

questions.question: Which of the following symptoms is a 27-year-old female patient presenting with thyroid swelling is unlikely to experience due to compression of adjacent structures?

options.A: Hoarseness of voice due to recurrent laryngeal nerve compression

questions.explanation: symptoms from compression: Hoarseness of voice due to recurrent laryngeal nerve compression (Option A): The recurrent laryngeal nerve is located posteromedial to the thyroid gland and can be compressed by an enlarged thyroid. This compression can lead to hoarseness of voice or vocal cord paralysis. Dysphagia due to esophagus compression (Option B): The esophagus can also be compressed by an enlarged thyroid due to its medial relation to the thyroid. This compression can cause difficulty in swallowing or dysphagia. Superior vena cava syndrome (Option C): Superior vena cava syndrome occurs when the superior vena cava becomes partially or completely blocked, leading to facial and upper extremity edema, breathlessness, and facial plethora. While thyroid swelling can cause compression on nearby structures, it does not typically involve or compress the superior vena cava due to its location in the superior mediastinum. Yet, it can occur rarely. Reference: Diseases of the Ear, Nose, and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 329

questions.question: Which structures pass between structures passing between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictor muscles.?

options.B: Internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal artery

questions.explanation: and glossopharyngeal nerve are the two structures passing between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictor muscles. The contents are derived from the 3 rd pharyngeal arch. Incorrect Options: Option B - Internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal artery: Internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal artery passes in the space between the middle and inferior constrictor muscles. Option C - Recurrent laryngeal nerve: Recurrent laryngeal nerve passes in the space below the inferior constrictor muscles. Option D - Ascending palatine artery: Ascending palatine artery passes through the sinus of Morgagni (space between the base of the skull and superior constrictor muscles ) Reference: .

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient comes with hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. The patient was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma, and surgical management was done. The post-operative image of the patient is given below. Which of the following surgery was done on this patient?
questions.explanation: entire larynx is removed. This procedure is typically performed in advanced laryngeal cancer cases that have not responded to other treatments, such as radiation therapy or chemotherapy. During a total laryngectomy, the trachea is re-routed to the front of the neck to create an opening called a stoma, which serves as the new airway. This procedure has significant implications for speech and swallowing, and patients typically require extensive rehabilitation to learn new communication and eating methods Indications for total laryngectomy: T4a with thyroid cartilage invasion. Stage 3 and 4a who cannot tolerate chemotherapy. Stage 3 and 4 recurrent tumours Bilateral arytenoid involvement. Incorrect Options: Partial laryngectomy (Option A): A partial laryngectomy is a surgical procedure in which only a part of the larynx is removed, leaving the rest of the organ intact. Percutaneous tracheostomy (Option B): Percutaneous tracheostomy is a minimally invasive procedure where a tube is inserted into the trachea via a small neck incision. It's commonly used for temporary or permanent airway support in conditions like obstructive sleep apnea or chronic respiratory failure, but it's not suitable for treating laryngeal cancer. Standard tracheostomy (Option C): A standard tracheostomy involves creating a neck incision to access the trachea, commonly used for temporary or permanent airway support in breathing difficulties. However, it's typically avoided in laryngeal cancer cases as it doesn't address the cancerous tissue in the larynx

questions.question: Which of the following symptoms does a patient with Reinke's edema classically present with?

options.C: Dysphagia of liquids more than solids
options.D: Dysphagia of solids more than liquids

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Diplophonia Explanation: Diplophonia is a classic symptom of Reinke's edema. Diplophonia, also known as "double voice," is a medical condition that causes a person to produce two simultaneous vocal sounds when speaking. This is usually caused by an abnormal vibration of the vocal cords, which results in a "shaky" or "quivering" voice that sounds like two voices speaking at once. Reinke's Edema Causes : Chronic vocal cord irritation (voice misuse, heavy smoking). Aka smokers larynx Chronic sinusitis, laryngopharyngeal reflux. Myxoedema More common in middle-aged men and women. Clinical Features : Hoarseness or husky voice. Use of false vocal cords for voice production, leading to a low-pitched, rough voice. Diplophonia Examination : Laryngoscopy: Fusiform swelling of vocal cords with a pale, translucent appearance. Ventricular bands may be hyperaemic and hypertrophic, obscuring true cords. Treatment : Decortication of vocal cords : Removal of a strip of epithelium, first on one side, then the other after 3-4 weeks. Voice rest Speech therapy : To improve proper voice production. Dysphonia (Option B): refers to any alteration in the voice, and while it may be present in patients with Reinke's edema, it is not a specific or classic symptom. Dysphagia of liquids or solids (Option C): is not a symptom associated with Reinke's edema, Dysphagia of liquids or solids (Option D): is not a symptom associated with Reinke's edema

questions.question: A patient who is a teacher by profession presents to the clinic with hoarseness of voice. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Vocal nodule Explanation: The most likely diagnosis in a patient who is a teacher and presents with hoarseness of voice is vocal nodule. This is because vocal nodules are the most common benign vocal fold lesions in individuals who use their voice extensively, such as teachers, singers, and actors. Vocal nodules are caused by vocal abuse or misuse, resulting in repeated trauma to the vocal folds, leading to the formation of small, benign growths. Symptoms of vocal nodules include hoarseness, voice fatigue, and difficulty hitting high notes. Vocal nodule and Vocal polyp Vocal Nodule (Singer or screamer's nodule) Vocal Polyp (Option A) Cause Chronic vocal abuse (teachers, actors, vendors or pop singers.) Sudden Vocal abuse like shouting (Men in the age group of 30-50 years). Heavy smoking Laterality Bilateral or symmetrical Unilateral Location Free edge of vocal cord at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd. This is the area of maximum vibration of the vocal cord. Same as vocal nodules. Appearance Sessile , Reddish in the early stage and white in the chronic stage Smooth and pedunculated. Symptoms Hoarseness, vocal fatigue and neck pain on prolonged phonation. Hoarseness of voice and diplophonia (double voice due to different vibrating frequencies of two vocal cords) Large polyps- dyspnea, stridor, choking. Treatment Initially, voice rest. If it fails - microscopic excision without injuring the vocal ligament Speech therapy Microscopic excision Speech therapy Vocal cysts (Option B): are fluid-filled sacs that can form on the vocal folds and are usually caused by a blocked mucous gland. Reinke's oedema (Option D): is a condition in which the vocal folds become swollen and fluid-filled due to chronic exposure to irritants such as smoking or gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Although Reinke's oedema can cause hoarseness, it is less likely to be the cause in a patient who is a teacher and presents with hoarseness of voice.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about laryngeal cancer stage T1bNOMO?

options.A: Both vocal cords involved and fixed
options.B: Both vocal cords involved, and no metastasis
options.C: One vocal cord involved and metastasis
options.D: One vocal cord involved, and mobile

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Both vocal cords involved, and no metastasis Explanation: The T1bN0M0 stage of laryngeal cancer indicates that the tumor is confined to both vocal cords, and is not metastatized Laryngeal ca-TNM classification: Supraglottis T1 Tumor is limited to one subsite of supraglottis with normal vocal cord mobility. T2 Tumor invades mucosa of more than one adjacent subsites of supraglottis or glottis or region outside the supraglottis (e.g. mucosa of base of tongue, vallecula, medial wall of pyriform sinus) without fixation of the larynx. T3 Tumor is limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades any of the following: postcricoid area, pre-epiglottic tissues, paraglottic space and/or minor thyroid cartilage invasion. T4a Tumor invades through the thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of tongue, strap muscles, thyroid or esophagus). T4b Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures Glottis T1 Tumor limited to vocal cord(s) (may involve anterior or posterior commissures) with normal mobility. T1a Tumor is limited to one vocal cord. T1b Tumor involves both vocal cords. T2 Tumor extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, and/or with impaired vocal cord mobility. T3 Tumor is limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades paraglottic space and/or minor thyroid cartilage erosion. T4a Tumor invades through thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscles of the tongue, strap muscles, thyroid, or esophagus). T4b Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases the carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures. Subglottis T1 Tumor is limited to the subglottis. T2 Tumor extends to the vocal cord(s) with normal or impaired mobility. T3 Tumor limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation. T4a Tumor invades cricoid or thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of tongue, strap muscles, thyroid or esophagus). T4b Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases the carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures. Regional lymph nodes (N) Nx Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed. N0 No regional lymph node metastasis. N1 Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, 3 cm or less in greatest dimension. N2 Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension. N2a Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension. N2b Metastasis in multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension. N2c Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension Na Metastasis in a lymph node more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension Distant metastasis Mx Distant metastasis cannot be assessed M0 No Distant metastasis M1 Distant metastasis Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat Dhingra 8th Edition Pg. 359, 360

questions.question: Which of the following treatment options is not recommended for a 4-year-old boy presenting with low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and barking cough for the past 5 days? The examination shows a hoarse voice, a moderately inflamed pharynx, and a slightly increased respiratory rate. The chest x-ray reveals subglottic narrowing resembling a steeple.
questions.explanation: infections. Mechanism : It is a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic effective against a broad spectrum of bacteria. Recommendation : Not recommended for croup, which is typically caused by a viral infection. Antibiotics like cefotaxime are not effective against viruses and therefore are not used in the treatment of viral croup unless there is a secondary bacterial infection, which is not indicated in this case. Other Options Option A. Nebulized racemic epinephrine: Indication : Used for moderate to severe croup to reduce airway swelling and relieve symptoms of stridor. Mechanism : Acts as a vasoconstrictor to reduce edema in the subglottic space. Recommendation : Appropriate for the treatment of croup. Option C. Helium oxygen mixture (Heliox): Indication : Used in severe cases of upper airway obstruction to improve airflow and reduce the work of breathing. Mechanism : Heliox is a mixture of helium and oxygen that is less dense than air, allowing it to flow more easily through narrowed airways. Recommendation : Appropriate as an adjunctive treatment in severe cases of croup to reduce respiratory distress. OptionD. Intramuscular dexamethasone: Indication : Used to reduce inflammation and edema in the airway. Mechanism : Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid that decreases inflammation and swelling in the subglottic area. Recommendation : Appropriate for the treatment of croup. It has been shown to reduce the severity and duration of symptoms. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following signs suggests the presence of a high tracheostomy?
questions.explanation: made at the level of the 1st tracheal ring, is primarily indicated in patients who have undergone a total laryngectomy for carcinoma of the larynx. During a total laryngectomy procedure, the entire larynx is removed to treat the cancer, necessitating the creation of a new opening in the trachea for breathing. By performing a high tracheostomy in these cases, the surgical opening is made in a clean area lower down, providing a clear airway and facilitating breathing without obstruction. Incorrect options Option A - Vocal cord palsy: Vocal cord palsy refers to the paralysis or weakness of the vocal cords, which can lead to hoarseness, difficulty speaking or swallowing, and breathing difficulties. High tracheostomy is not directly indicated for vocal cord palsy as it does not address the underlying issue of vocal cord dysfunction. Option B - Tracheomalacia: Tracheomalacia is a condition characterized by the weakness or floppiness of the tracheal walls, leading to airway collapse during breathing. It can result in breathing difficulties, noisy breathing (stridor), and recurrent respiratory infections. Option C - Foreign body obstruction: Foreign body obstruction occurs when an object becomes lodged in the airway, blocking the flow of air. This can be a life-threatening emergency, requiring immediate intervention to remove the foreign body and restore the airway. Reference: .

questions.question: What type of lesions are associated with the presence of inspiratory stridor?
questions.explanation: refers to a high-pitched, wheezing sound heard during inspiration. It is caused by the partial obstruction of the upper airway, which disrupts the normal airflow. Supraglottic lesions involve structures above the level of the vocal cords , such as the epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, and false vocal cords . When these structures are affected or swollen, they can cause partial obstruction of the airway during inspiration, resulting in inspiratory stridor. Incorrect options: Option B. Subglottic : Subglottic lesions refer to abnormalities or obstructions in the area below the vocal cords but above the trachea. While subglottic lesions can cause airway obstruction, they typically result in both inspiratory and expiratory stridor, as they affect airflow in both directions. Option C. Tracheal : Tracheal lesions specifically involve the trachea, which is the tube connecting the larynx (voice box) to the bronchi. Tracheal lesions can cause a range of respiratory symptoms, but inspiratory stridor is less commonly associated with isolated tracheal lesions. Option D. Bronchus: Bronchial lesions primarily affect the bronchi, which are the branching tubes that carry air to the lungs. Bronchial lesions are not typically associated with inspiratory stridor as they are located further down the respiratory tract. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below:
questions.explanation: of the larynx, which is a characteristic appearance of laryngeal papilloma . Laryngeal papillomas are benign growths caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. Clinical Features Management Options Benign growth Regular monitoring of growth and symptoms Surgical removal of papillomas Adjuvant therapies such as laser treatment or cryotherapy Caused by HPV infection Vaccination against HPV (for prevention) Wart-like or grape-like projections Voice therapy and vocal cord exercises Hoarseness Voice therapy and vocal cord exercises Surgical removal of papillomas Stridor Breathing difficulties Airway management and emergency intervention Incorrect options: Option A. Reinke's edema : Reinke's edema refers to a swelling or fluid accumulation within the superficial layer of the vocal cords. It typically results from long-term exposure to irritants, such as smoking or vocal abuse. Option B. Malignancy: Malignancy refers to the presence of cancerous cells. While cancer can affect the vocal cords, the image does not suggest a malignant lesion. Laryngeal cancer typically presents with different features, such as irregular or ulcerated masses, not grape-like projections. Option C. Tracheomalacia: Tracheomalacia refers to the weakness or collapse of the tracheal cartilage, which leads to breathing difficulties. Reference: .

questions.question: What would be the diagnosis for a 2-year-old child who has been experiencing fever, a cough that sounds like barking, and stridor for the past 2 days?
questions.explanation: diagnosis for a 2-year-old child presenting with fever, barking cough, and stridor. This condition involves inflammation and swelling of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi, causing upper respiratory symptoms . Diagnosis Clinical assessment based on symptoms such as the characteristic cough, stridor, and respiratory distress. In severe cases, imaging studies like neck x-rays or laryngoscopy may be performed. Incorrect Options: Option A - Acute Epiglottitis is characterized by inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis, leading to severe respiratory distress and a high risk of airway obstruction. It typically presents with drooling, difficulty swallowing, and a high fever. These symptoms are not mentioned in the case, making it less likely. Option B - COVID-19 Is the incorrect answer. Option C - Adenoiditis refers to inflammation of the adenoids, which are located in the back of the nasal cavity. It may cause nasal congestion, sore throat, and difficulty breathing through the nose. However, it does not typically present with barking cough or stridor, so it is less likely in this case. Reference: .

questions.question: Life-saving muscle of vocal cords is:
questions.explanation: cords during inspiration, allowing air to flow into the lungs. When this muscle contracts, it pulls the arytenoid cartilage away from the midline, causing the vocal cords to separate and create an open airway . This is essential for normal breathing and is considered th e primary muscle responsible for keeping the airway open. Incorrect options: Option B - Lateral cricoarytenoid: The lateral cricoarytenoid muscle is involved in adducting or bringing together the vocal cords during phonation or speaking. It is not considered a life-saving muscle for maintaining the airway. Option C - Transverse arytenoid: The transverse arytenoid muscle is also involved in adducting the vocal cords, assisting in their closure during phonation. It is not primarily responsible for maintaining the airway. Option D - Thyroarytenoid: The thyroarytenoid muscle is involved in controlling the tension and position of the vocal cords, allowing for modulation of pitch and voice production. It is not specifically responsible for maintaining the airway.

questions.question: Adam's apple seen in boys is because of:
questions.explanation: laryngeal prominence, is formed by the thyroid cartilage , which is larger and more prominent in males. It becomes more apparent during puberty due to hormonal changes. Incorrect Options: Option A . Hyoid bone: The hyoid bone is a U-shaped bone located in the neck, but it is not responsible for the prominence seen as Adam's apple. Option B . Tracheal rings: The tracheal rings are cartilaginous rings that provide support to the trachea. They do not contribute to the development of the Adam's apple. Option D . Cricoid cartilage: The cricoid cartilage is located below the thyroid cartilage and is not responsible for Adam's apple prominence. Reference: .

questions.question: What are the initial signs of vocal fold growth?
questions.explanation: change in voice quality or hoarseness . This change in voice may be characterized by a raspy, breathy, or rough quality. It may also be accompanied by a decrease in vocal range or difficulty in producing certain sounds or pitches. The correct option is B - Change of voice. Incorrect options: Option A - Cough: While vocal fold growth or vocal cord lesions can sometimes lead to a cough, it is not typically an early symptom. Option C - Fatigue voice: Fatigue or vocal fatigue may occur as a result of vocal fold growth, but it is not an early symptom. Option D - Pain: Pain is not typically an early symptom of vocal fold growth or vocal cord lesions unless there is an underlying inflammatory or infectious process. Reference: .

questions.question: What are the structures that are not visible during indirect laryngoscopy?
questions.explanation: the point of contact between the vocal cords anteriorly, is not directly visible during indirect laryngoscopy. Can be seen in some cases but may be difficult to see if the epiglottis is overhanging. Incorrect Options ; Option B - Tracheal rings: This option is incorrect. Tracheal rings through the glottic chink (Rima glottides is visible) Option C - Epiglottis: This option is incorrect. The epiglottis, which is a flap of tissue located at the base of the tongue, is visible during indirect laryngoscopy. Option D - False Vocal Cord: This option is incorrect. The false vocal cord, also known as the ventricular fold, is visible during indirect laryngoscopy. Reference: Tuli's Textook of Ear, Nose and Throat

questions.question: Which muscle in the larynx is essential for saving lives as it retracts the vocal cords to enable breathing?
questions.explanation: muscle is the only abductor muscle of the vocal cords, meaning it pulls them apart for breathing, allowing air to pass through the larynx. Incorrect Options: Option A - Cricothyroid: This option is incorrect. The cricothyroid muscle is responsible for adjusting the tension of the vocal cords, but it does not pull them back for breathing. Option C - Lateral Cricoarytenoid: This option is incorrect. The lateral cricoarytenoid muscle is involved in adducting the vocal cords for phonation, not for breathing. Option D - Transverse Arytenoid: This option is incorrect. The transverse arytenoid muscle is also involved in adducting the vocal cords for phonation, not for breathing.

questions.question: All are parts of the Hypopharynx except:
questions.explanation: hypopharynx. Hypopharynx There are three subdivisions of the hypopharynx. They are (3Ps) Pyriform fossa: These are two depressions on the lateral sides of the aryepiglottic folds. They are also known as the smuggler's pouch. Post cricoid region: It is a depression in the midline below the arytenoids. Posterior pharyngeal wall: It is a continuous wall of the hypopharynx. The hypopharynx: The Hypopharynx continues down to the esophagus. Incorrect options: Option A - Posterior pharyngeal wall: The posterior pharyngeal wall is part of the hypopharynx. Option B - Pyriform Sinus: The pyriform sinuses are part of the hypopharynx. Option C - Post-cricoid area: The post-cricoid area is part of the hypopharynx. Reference: .

questions.question: In which of the following scenarios is high tracheostomy performed?
questions.explanation: may be performed in cases of carcinoma of the larynx to provide an adequate airway below the tumor. Tracheostomy Surgical opening in the trachea is called a tracheostomy. If a tracheostomy is done at the level of the 1st tracheal ring. This is called a High tracheostomy. Mainly done in patients with total laryngectomy. Incorrect options: Option A - Laryngeal papilloma: This option is incorrect. Laryngeal papilloma is a condition characterized by the presence of benign growths in the larynx. It does not require a high tracheostomy. Option C - Bilateral vocal fold palsy: This option is incorrect. Bilateral vocal fold palsy refers to the paralysis or weakness of both vocal folds. It does not require a high tracheostomy. Option D - Laryngomalacia: This option is incorrect. Laryngomalacia is a condition in infants where the tissues of the larynx are floppy, leading to partial airway obstruction. It does not typically require a high tracheostomy. Reference: .

questions.question: The narrowest part of airway in an infant is:
questions.explanation: of the airway in an infant, which is located below the glottis. Rima glottidis: Space between between 2 true cords Ventricle: Space between false cords above and true cords below Elongation from ventricle: Saccule Incorrect options: Option A - Supraglottis: This option is incorrect. The supraglottis is the region above the glottis and is not the narrowest part of the airway in an infant. Option B - Glottis: This option is incorrect. While the glottis is a critical part of the airway, it is not the narrowest part of the airway in an infant. Option D - Epiglottis: This option is incorrect. The epiglottis is a flap of tissue that covers the glottis during swallowing and protects the airway. However, it is not the narrowest part of the airway in an infant. Reference: .

questions.question: Which cartilage is responsible for the protrusion of the Adam's apple?
questions.explanation: prominence, is primarily due to the cartilage known as the thyroid cartilage. The thyroid cartilage is the largest cartilage of the larynx and forms the front part of the laryngeal skeleton. In males, it tends to be more prominent, giving rise to the visible Adam's apple. Unpaired/ Hyaline Ala (2 ALA of single cartilage) 90 in males 120 in females Oblique line of thyroid cartilage gives attachment to Sternum to thyroid: Sternothyroid muscle Thyroid to hyoid: Thyrohyoid Thyroid to pharynx: Thyropharyngus Thyroid cartilage gives attachment to Epiglottis: Above Vocal cords: Below Incorrect options: Option B: The cricoid cartilage is a ring-shaped cartilage located below the thyroid cartilage in the larynx. It forms the base of the larynx and provides support to the vocal cords. The cricoid cartilage does not contribute to the protrusion of the Adam's apple. Option C: Hyoid; The hyoid bone is a U-shaped bone located in the neck, above the larynx. It serves as a point of attachment for various muscles and ligaments in the neck and plays a role in swallowing and speech. However, it is not directly associated with the protrusion of the Adam's apple. Reference: .

questions.question: Which nerve injury is responsible for the development of postoperative aspiration in a patient who underwent surgery at the lateral part of the skull without any change in voice?
questions.explanation: glossopharyngeal nerve can disrupt the normal sensory feedback involved in the swallowing reflex. This can result in impaired swallowing and aspiration, particularly in the postoperative period when swallowing may be compromised. Incorrect Options: Option A - High vagal injury: The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) plays a role in several functions, including swallowing and voice production. However, a "high vagal injury" typically refers to damage to the vagus nerve at or above the level of the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN) and recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) branches. High vagal injuries are more likely to affect voice production rather than cause isolated aspiration without voice change. Option B - Recurrent laryngeal nerve: The recurrent laryngeal nerve (a branch of the vagus nerve) innervates the intrinsic muscles of the larynx, which are crucial for voice production. Damage can lead to vocal cord paralysis and voice changes, but it is not typically associated with isolated aspiration without voice change. Option C - Superior laryngeal nerve: The superior laryngeal nerve (also a branch of the vagus nerve) has two branches: the internal branch and the external branch. Damagecan affect the sensory innervation of the larynx above the vocal cords but is less likely to cause aspiration without voice change. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) plays a role in swallowing and sensory functions in the throat, including the sensation of the oropharynx. Damage can lead to impaired swallowing and potential aspiration. Reference: .

questions.question: What is the probable cause of surgical emphysema in a patient following an emergency tracheostomy?
questions.explanation: around the tracheostomy site can obstruct the normal passage of air, causing air to escape into the surrounding subcutaneous tissues. This can lead to the accumulation of air under the skin, resulting in surgical emphysema. The tight suture creates a seal that prevents air from escaping through the tracheostomy tube, forcing it into the surrounding tissues instead. Incorrect Options: Option A. High tracheostomy: A high tracheostomy refers to a tracheostomy performed above the second or third tracheal cartilage. While a high tracheostomy can cause complications, such as injury to blood vessels or the thyroid gland, it is not directly associated with surgical emphysema. Option B: Tear in posterior tracheal wall A tear in the posterior tracheal wall can lead to air escaping into the mediastinum and potentially causing pneumomediastinum rather than subcutaneous emphysema. Option C. Block in tracheostomy: A block in the tracheostomy tube can lead to respiratory distress and the buildup of secretions. While it requires immediate attention, it is not directly related to surgical emphysema. Reference: .

questions.question: What investigation is carried out immediately after a child is suspected of having inhaled a foreign body?
questions.explanation: the initial investigation carried out. A chest X-ray can help identify the location and potential presence of a foreign body in the lungs or airways. It provides a quick and non-invasive way to assess the situation and determine the appropriate course of action. Incorrect Options: Option A - Rigid bronchoscopy : Rigid bronchoscopy is a procedure in which a rigid tube is inserted into the airways to visualize and remove foreign bodies or other obstructions. While this is indeed a procedure that may be carried out to remove a foreign body from a child's lung, it is not typically the immediate investigation performed right after a child ingests or inhales a foreign body. Option C - Direct laryngoscopy: Direct laryngoscopy is a procedure that involves examining the larynx (voice box) and adjacent structures using a laryngoscope. While this procedure might be used to examine the upper airway and larynx, it is not typically the first investigation performed when a foreign body is suspected in the lower airways or lungs. Option D - Flexible endoscopy: Flexible endoscopy involves using a flexible tube with a camera on the end to visualize internal structures. While this procedure can be used to examine the airways and remove foreign bodies, it might not be the immediate investigation performed right after a child inhales or ingests a foreign body. Reference: .
